Facility¿s Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that contains procedures, which are designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

Although ammonia is a listed toxic substance, it is also a ubiquitous material, which is used by the surrounding farmers for fertilizer. Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125 Exemptions ¿ Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68).

III.	Facility Identification
The Dawn Foods facility is located at 1300 East Summit Street in Crown Point, Indiana. The facility is a manufacturer of baked goods including baked muffins, raw frozen cookies, puff pastry and Danish doughs, fruit sticks, cinnamon rolls and frozen batters. The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one refrigeration system onsite. The system originally contained a charge of 9,600 pounds of ammonia. It was recently modified via the addition of a compressor, four new evaporators and a floor warming system. The amount of ammonia present in the modified refrigeration system is approximately 13,500 pounds, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. The ammonia receiver tank is identified as Vessel +25 and is located inside the main building in the engine room.  The receiver tank is not located near any other processes.  

IV.	Hazard Assessment ¿ Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
While a catastrophic release is not expected to occur, as required by the Rule, Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios were evaluated to estimate the potential offsite consequences (i.e., offsite consequence analysis (OCA)) to the public or the environment from the potential accidental release of ammonia. 

Pursuant to the Rule, ¿the greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity¿ was used.

The worst-case toxic accidental release scenario is a catastrophic failure of the primary ammonia receiver (approximately 30 psig), Vessel +25, which is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 10,800 pounds (80 percent vessel capacity). However, this vessel is designed to hold almost the entire ammonia system charge in the event that emergency shutdown of the system is required (its actual capacity is 13,452 pounds).  Therefore, the worse case scenario is based on a release from Vessel +25 containing 13,400 pounds of ammonia (using EPA's rounding guidance to two significant figures per the RMP Submit User's Manual dated January 4, 1999).

EPA¿s Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration (EPA 550-B-00-006, May 2000) Exhibit 4-4, shows that under a worst-case release scenario ¿ whereby the entire 13,400 pound quantity of anhydrous ammonia is released in a 10-minute period, the toxic endpoint distance is 1.0 mile (note that if 13,500 pounds is used as a worst-case quantity, the toxic endpoint distance is still 1.0 mile). The ERPG-2 airborne toxic endpoint concentration of 200 parts per million (ppm) or 0.14 mg/L is the maximum which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual¿s ability to take protective action. Based upon year 2000 census data, the population within a radius of 1.0 mile is 2,937.

It should be noted that the worst-case scenario is an extremely unlikely event especially since most of the time, the ammonia is distributed within the piping of many refrigeration subsystems within the facility building ¿ and is not contained within this large vessel.  During normal operation, Vessel +25 is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 10,800 pounds (80 percent vessel capacity). However, in actuality, this vessel only holds five percent of the ammonia system charge during nor

mal operation. 

 In the event of a failure in the ammonia refrigeration system, the system is designed to shut down and a series of three vessels (including Vessel +25) is designed to collect and hold the ammonia charge.  It is extremely unlikely that the majority of the system charge would need to be held in Vessel +25 and even more unlikely that a release would then occur from this vessel.

V.	Hazard Assessment ¿ Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
An ARS was modeled for ammonia in the hazard assessment and assumes that a leak occurs in a pipe joint, seal, valve or weld. ¿Guidance average¿ weather conditions including 3 meters per second wind speed and a D stability class at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees C were used. The simplified Bernoulli equation was employed in the ARS OCA. Using a conservative pressure of 130 pounds per square inch (gauge) with a hole-diameter of up to 0.37 inches, the continuous release rate would be 250 pounds per minute, which would result in a 200-ppm toxic endpoint distance of 0.1 miles (Guidance Tables: Exhibits 4-5 and 4-6) in this urban setting. No mitigation measures were considered.

A small population group may be affected by the ARS due to the close proximity of commercial business to the facility; however, the LandView Census estimator did not indicate any offsite receptors.

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur in August of 2006 in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
·	Employee Participation ¿ Dawn Foods

has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program ensures employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  Employees at Dawn Foods have assisted in developing the initial PHA for the ammonia process and will participate in updating and revalidating the PHA every five years.  In addition, employees have assisted in the development of other PSM/RMP information such as the development of operating and preventative maintenance procedures.
·	Process Safety Information ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of August 2003.
·	Process Hazard Review ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough    to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program has been established to ensure PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and to ensure findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. The PHA was completed on August 20, 2003.
·	Operating Procedures ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  The Standard Operating Procedures manual was completed on August 20, 2003. Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.
·	Training ¿ Dawn Foods has develo

ped a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
·	Management of Change ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
·	Pre-Startup Review ¿Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
·	Mechanical Integrity ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Preventative maintenance procedures have been established within written operating procedures dated August 20, 2003.  In addition, a preventative maintenance database application has been established to assist in documenting and tracking preventative maintenance activities.
·	Contractor Qualifications ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers¿ safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Dawn Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
·	Incident Investigation ¿ Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results

in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure also makes provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
·	Compliance Audit ¿ The facility was not subject to the RMP regulations until August 20, 2003 when the ammonia refrigeration system was modified to include an additional compressor,four new evaporators and a floor warming system.  The ammonia refrigeration system was modified to hold a charge of 13,500 pounds of ammonia. A compliance audit will be conducted by August 20, 2006.  Dawn Foods has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Dawn Foods¿ PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.
·	Hot Work Permits ¿ Dawn Foods has implemented the hot work program and developed a best management practice for hot work.

The following manuals were completed on August 20, 2003 for Dawn Foods by Hygieneering for the facility¿s ammonia process:  Process Safety Information Manual, Process Safety Management Manual, Process Hazard Analysis, and the Standard Operating Procedures.  These documents are required as part of Dawn Foods Risk Management Program.

The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:

·	Process safety information is provided to all employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.
·	In-depth process hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel using techniques approved under the PSM standard.
·	Written operating procedures (kept up-to-date) are used for training and guiding the work of operators.
·	Training is provided to all employees upon hire, and refresher training is given annually or upon request.
·

Operators, mechanics, and contractor personnel are qualified, trained and in the general hazards in the facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety.
·	Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted to insure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied prior to starting new or modified equipment.
·	A program is in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process, which includes written procedures, training requirements, equipment deficiency requests for employees, work orders, scheduled maintenance, and computerized documentation.
·	A hot work permit system assures that work is done safely and properly.
·	A management of change system is in place to ensure that changes are managed safely.
·	Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.
·	Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed.

This systematic approach to process safety at Dawn Foods involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety. The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of our operations, maintenance, and management personnel are a key element in reducing and mitigating accidents.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include safety interlocks/alarms to prevent ammonia (1) overfilling (flooding) of various subsystem vessels; and (2) over-pressurization, whereby control valves fail ¿open¿ to reduce and distribute system pressure. There are 12 ammonia detectors distributed in key areas around the facility.

The building housing the ammonia tanks is locked to deter theft, vandalism, and terrorism.  The only access to the roof is inside of the building.
 
VII.	Five-Year Accident History
Dawn Foods has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

VIII

.	Emergency Response Program
Dawn Foods has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), updated on December 15, 2003 to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. Response activities will be coordinated with the Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) also known as the Lake County Hazardous Material Planning Committee, the Crown Point Fire Department and the Lake County Fire Chiefs Association HAZMAT Team. This coordination effort includes providing the fire departments with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department personnel to discuss facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel.

The facility maintains an ERP on file at the plant. According to the ERP, facility employees are responsible for responding to accidental releases of ammonia up to 300 ppm. The plan includes annual training of all employees on evacuation procedures and emergency notification procedures. The plan also includes annual training for emergency response team members. It identifies the Emergency Response Coordinators, Evacuation Coordinators and alternates. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant will be included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee. Dawn Foods also coordinates with the Crown Point Fire Department and the Lake County Fire Chiefs Association HAZMAT Team on emergency response activities. 

The facility has a windsock present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release.

XI.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Dawn Food¿s operations. Dawn Foods recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Dawn Foods. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant will be included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee. 

New administrative procedures: On an annual basis, Dawn Foods management including the General Manager, Maintenance Manager, Safety Director, and the Stationary Engineer will review local (county) and state emergency planning procedures including the LEPC¿s current Emergency Operations Plan.

Dawn Foods will need to certify that this document has been reviewed and discussed with the LEPC, the Crown Point Fire Department and the L

s procedures for using and maintaining emergency response equipment as required.

The facility's Onsite Incident Commander or Emergency Response Coordinator (General Manager) is responsible for notifying onsite emergency response personnel, emergency response contractors and local, state and federal agencies of releases. The Emergency Response Coordinator (General Manager) is responsible for submitting written communication concerning releases to local, state and federal agencies.

The facility¿s Evacuation Coordinator (Safety Director) is responsible for coordinating site evacuation in the event of a release that requires evacuation.

The facility¿s Emergency Response Plan is maintained onsite as part of the Risk Management Program. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are included in the facility¿s Emergency Action Plan / Emergency Response Plan.

X.	Spill Reporting / Environmental Release Procedures
In the event of a catastrophic release, call 911.

1.	Whenever there is any type of chemical release, the shift engineer, maintenance mechanic, or manager on duty must complete a chemical release incident report within 24 hours of the release. The report should be forwarded to the General Manager and Maintenance Manager and then should be given to the Safety Director and to the Stationary Engineer. The Safety Director and the Stationary Engineer will keep the reports on file for a period of six years.

2.	If an ammonia release has a flow rate of 100 pounds or greater in a 24 period, the following steps should be taken:
a.	Immediately contact Dawn Foods General Manager. Dawn Foods (Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Response Coordinator) will notify the appropriate state and federal agencies. The facility phone number for the

Onsite Incident Commander is (219) 662-3296, Extension 120, and his cellular phone number is (219) 712-7607. If you cannot reach the Onsite Incident Commander, contact the Alternate Emergency Response Coordinators until someone is reached. The facility¿s 24-hour emergency number is (219) 662-3296.  If necessary, contact Dawn Foods Corporate Director of Health and Safety at the following phone number during daytime hours only:  (800) 248-1144.

If you cannot contact anyone at the above numbers, proceed to the next steps.

In the event of a catastrophic release, call 911.

b.	The manager on the shift must notify the Crown Point Fire Department (911: emergency / (219) 662-3248: non-emergency) and the Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC - (219) 755-3512) within 24 hours of the incident. When reporting the incident, the Emergency Notification Form must be completed. 

Only department managers are authorized to report releases (except in the event of a catastrophic release, in which case, call 911). Within 36 hours of the first phone call a second phone call must be made to the Crown Point Fire Department (911 - emergency / (219) 662-3248 ¿ non-emergency) and to the Lake County LEPC (219-755-3512) to advise them further on the status of the release. At this time a second Emergency Notification Form must be completed. 

c.	The Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Response Coordinator (or department manager as directed by the Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Response Coordinator) should also contact the Indiana Department of the Environment (IDEM) after calling the Crown Point Fire Department to put them on alert. The phone number for the IDEM is (317) 233-7745. The reporter will provide this agency with the same information as provided to the fire department.  He will note that the call was made and list the contact person on the Emergency Notification Form.

XII.	Management Program
The owner or operator of a stationary source with processes subject to Program 2 and 3 must develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  The Emergency Chain of Command identified in the Emergency Response Plan developed for the Dawn Foods facility outlines this organization, and assigns specific responsibilities to each position.  Additionally John Hilzley is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
